metadata.case_name: Road-side Station Masters v. General Manager, Central Railways & Ors.

facts.text: Petitioners are Road-side Station Masters challenging constitutionality of channel of promotion for Guards to higher grade Station Masters posts as notified in Central Railway Weekly Gazette No. 3 dated November 23, 1951.

Under notification, Guards have two lines of promotion: C grade to B grade (Rs. 100-185) to A grade (Rs. 150-225); or by Slip 45 examination, C grade Guards to Station Masters on Rs. 150-225, then higher scales up to Rs. 360-500.
B and A grade Guards passing Slip 45 eligible for Station Masters on Rs. 200-300 and higher.
Road-side Station Masters on Rs. 80-170 (formerly Rs. 64-170) reach Rs. 150-225 only after intermediate Rs. 100-185; Rs. 100-185 Station Masters reach Rs. 200-300 after Rs. 150-225.
This places Road-side Station Masters at disadvantage against Guards on same pay scales.
Petitioner No. 2 after 32 years service in Rs. 100-185; Guards of equal status reached gazetted rank.
Petitioner No. 3 reached Rs. 150-225 after 21 years; Guards of standing reached Rs. 360-500, juniors superseded.
Petitioner No. 4 after 6.5 years + 2.5 years exams still Rs. 80-170; Guards entitled to Rs. 150-225.
Respondents deny Guards reach Rs. 150-225 at younger age than Road-side Station Masters.
Appendix II Indian Railway Establishment Code Vol. I classifies subordinate staff into 7 branches, Transportation (Traffic) into groups: Station Masters, Guards, Outdoor Clerical Staff.
Station Masters group: separate recruitment, training, promotions from Signaller etc.
Guards group: separate recruitment, training, promotions.
Guards becoming Station Masters via Slip 45 cease to be Guards.
Channel peculiar to Central Railways, not other zones.

legal_issues.text: Whether the channel of promotion enabling Guards to become Station Masters contravenes Article 16(1) by denying equal opportunity in matters of promotion to Road-side Station Masters.
Whether matters of promotion are included in 'matters relating to employment' under Article 16(1).
Whether Road-side Station Masters and Guards form the same class of employees for equality of opportunity in promotion.

petitioner_arguments.text: Channel of promotion enables Guards to bypass intermediate stages to Station Masters scales, denying equal opportunity under Art. 16(1) to Road-side Station Masters.
Guards reach higher posts at younger age, blocking promotions for older Station Masters.
Road-side Station Masters and Guards form one class.

respondent_arguments.text: Denies Guards become Station Masters on Rs. 150-225 at younger age.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 16(1) guarantees equality for citizens in employment/appointment; assuming promotions included, equality only between members of same class, not different classes.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Equality predicated only as between persons seeking/obtaining same employment.

court_reasoning.text: Road-side Station Masters and Guards are separate classes: recruited separately, trained separately, distinct promotion channels per Appendix II rules.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Only contact is Guards passing Slip 45 to become Station Masters, then cease being Guards.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide if promotions under 'matters relating to employment' as different classes anyway.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petitioners and Guards distinct classes, no equality issue.

holdings.text: Equality of opportunity in promotion applies only between members of same class of employees, not separate classes.
Road-side Station Masters and Guards are distinct separate classes.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition under Art. 32 for enforcement of fundamental right under Art. 16(1) equality in employment/promotion.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Railway Establishment Code Vol. I, Appendix II
statutes_cited.relevance: Classifies staff into branches/groups with separate recruitment, training, promotion channels for Station Masters and Guards.

outcome.summary: The petition under Article 32 challenging the promotion channel for Guards as violating Article 16(1) is rejected, as Station Masters and Guards are distinct classes with no denial of equal opportunity.

key_quotes.text: "Equality of opportunity in matters of promotion, must mean equality as between members of the same class of employees, and not equality between members of separate, independent classes."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding defining scope of Art. 16(1) for promotions.

key_quotes.text: "The concept of equality can have no existence except with reference to matters which are common as between individuals, between whom equality is predicated."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains when equality applies in employment.
